,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Dr. Anas Alam Faizli''', known as Anas is a [[Malaysians
date=November 2016}}: Malaysian]] non-political Asset Facility Management business leader, a construction and an upstream Oil and Gas professional, a scholar, an [[activist]], and an [[author]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=ANAS ALAM FAIZLI ENGINEER, SCHOLAR, EDUCATOR AND AUTHOR
column6: accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> He holds a post graduate doctorate in Business Administration and currently a leader in a Government Linked Company (GLC), previously a Director of a Malaysian Multi-National Company (MNC),<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> a leading international heavy steel construction company. Anas also serves as the Treasurer for the Malaysian Asset and Project Management (MAPMA) <ref>{{cite web
column12: url=http://www.mapma.org.my/?q=council-members}}</ref> and formerly the Assistant Honorary Secretary for the Malaysian Oil and Gas Services Council (2016-2018). He is also a certified Oil and Gas Expert by Malaysia's Ministry of Human Resource and an Industrialised Building System (IBS) Professional certified by CIDB Malaysia. Additionally he also co-founded several non-governmental organisations and an economic research think tank. His books are bestseller titled Rich Malaysia, Poor Malaysians and ''Malaysia Kaya, Rakyat Miskin.''

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Anas was born on 5 December 1980 (Hijri Calendar: 27th of Muharram 1401AH) at the [[Nether Edge Hospital]], Sheffield, England as the first child of ten siblings. He was raised in a family of moderate Muslims. Both his parents are lecturers at the [[University of Technology, Malaysia
date=November 2016}}: Universiti Teknologi Malaysia (UTM)]]. Anas’ mother is from Kedah and his father is from Kuala Lumpur. Anas' maternal grandfather, Abdul Rahman bin Ibrahim was a Headmaster of a government school in Simpang Empat, Alor Setar Kedah.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Anas’ paternal grandfather, Mohd Zain bin Abu<ref>{{cite web
column3: url=http://aafaizli.com/biografi-mohd-zain-bin-abu-1923-2009/}}</ref> is of Bugis descent while his paternal grandmother, Siti Hajar binti Othman is of Minangkabau descent. Siti Hajar's father, Haji Othman bin Haji Abdullah,<ref>{{cite book
column9: location=New London and Haven}}</ref> is a nationalist and a freedom fighter, founder of Seruan Azhar of Egypt and also the Malaya newspaper, Majlis. Haji Othman was a close friend of Indonesia's First Vice President, [[Mohammad Hatta]].<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Matinya Seorang Pelopor - Othman Abdullah Dalam Kenangan

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Haji Othman's grandfather, [[Mohamed Taib bin Haji Abdul Samad
date=November 2016}}: Haji Mohd Taib bin Haji Abdul Samad]], is regarded as an influenced tycoon in the early history of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Haji Taib owned tin mines, plantation land and large numbers of houses and shops mostly in Malay Street (Jalan Melayu), Kuala Lumpur. Haji Taib was a close acquaintance of Sultan Abdul Samad. In the late 19th century, Haji Taib was one of the wealthiest merchants and development centre of city, Kampung Baru.<ref>{{cite journal
column5: title=Merantau ke Kuala Lumpur: Tradisi Merantau dan Berdagang Masyarakat Minang

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Anas receives his preliminary education from Sekolah Rendah Islam Al-Amin (SRIAA) which was located in Jalan Gurney, Kuala Lumpur. The school was founded by [[Jamaah Islah Malaysia
date=November 2016}}: Pertubuhan Jamaah Islah Malaysia (JIM)]], now known as Pertubuhan Ikram Malaysia (IKRAM). Anas did his lower secondary school in [[:ms:Sekolah Menengah Islam Al-Amin Gombak

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: After his Penilaian Menengah Rendah (PMR) result, he was offered and entrance to the [[Malay College Kuala Kangsar]] (MCKK) and [[Sultan Alam Shah Islamic College]] (Malay: Kolej Islam Sultan Alam Shah - KISAS) which he accepted the latter. In KISAS, Anas was the President of the International Club and in 1997 he represented the school as part of the debating team for the Piala Perdana Menteri (PPM). The School won Central Zone championship by defeating debaters from the Royal Military College (RMC), [[Sekolah Seri Puteri]] (SSP), and [[Sekolah Alam Shah]] (SAS). KISAS won third place at national level.
After KISAS, Anas pursued his bachelor's degree from the Universiti Teknologi Malaysia. In 2011, he became the pioneer sole graduate<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title=Pioneers of Master of Project Management
column4: date=15 April 2010}}</ref> with Distinction for [[Master of Science in Project Management
column5: Master of Project Management]] from the [[Open University Malaysia]]. In 2015, he again became the pioneer sole graduate for [[Doctor of Business Administration]]<ref>{{cite news

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Anas was chosen as the \"valedictorian\" graduate and delivered a speech representing 7,506 graduates at OUM's 17th Convocation. In his speech, he urged all the graduates to become the candles that light the way for society, to be a leader for their family, their community, in the workplace and outside, and to make their voice heard.

Anas did his internship with IBM for six months in 2000. He joined the Oil and Gas industry with Sime [[Sembcorp]] Engineering and left as Assistant Project Manager in 2004. Anas then spent 15 months with Petronas Carigali Sdn Bhd as a Senior Project Controller. After that, Anas served Talisman Malaysia Limited for 10 years in various project management and developmental Oil and Gas roles in Engineering, Construction, Hookup and Commissioning, Offshore and Installation.<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title=Anas Alam Faizli- This oil and gas professional with a doctorate in business administration speaks his heart out about his life and career – MotivateMe.in

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: In the ten years, he served two years working onshore Vietnam and two years offshore at the Vietnam-Malaysia border and other assignments.<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title=My oil and gas adventure - Anas Alam Faizli
column4: work=english.astroawani.com}}</ref> As he is a certified Oil and Gas expert, the media<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Show us your numbers, oil and gas expert tells govt - The Rakyat Post
column9: title=Subsidy cut surprising, says oil and gas expert - The Rakyat Post
column12: date=2 October 2014}}</ref> get his quote for business related issues on Oil and Gas. After the crude oil price falls in 2014, he joined as Director of a Malaysian Multi-National Company (MNC), a leading international heavy steel construction company in 2015. In 2017, he joined Edgenta PROPEL Berhad (a subsidiary of UEM Edgenta Berhad) as the Operations Head for the maintenance of the ~1,000 km North-South Expressway and currently heads its Public Sector & Industry Engagement activities.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Anas is an occasional contributor for The Edge, The Star, Astro Awani and online portals. In 2014, Gerakbudaya published his best-seller book, entitled ''Rich Malaysia, Poor Malaysians: Essays on Energy, Economy and Education''. A Malay version of the book, ''[http://www.gerakbudayaebooks.com/store/p49/Malaysia_Kaya%2C_Rakyat_Miskin.html Malaysia Kaya, Rakyat Miskin]'' was also published the same year. Both versions was launched by [[Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah]], Malaysia's Former Finance Minister and also the Founding Chairman and CEO of Petronas in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web
date=November 2016}}: title=Tengku Razaleigh' Speech at RMPM Book Launching

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah applauded Anas' intellectual discipline in completing the writing which he describes as demanding mental toughness, tenacity and absolute patience. Policy makers, scholars and corporate figures are of the opinion that the views and ideas presented in the book can be usefully adopted for the formulation of policies by political parties and the government.<ref>{{cite web

On Energy, the book touches on how Petronas plays it roles in its significant contribution to the country. It also explains the history, the regulations and mechanism used and the secret behind Petronas’ success.<ref>{{cite news

On economy, the book introduces the Malaysia's inequality dilemma, the myth of the rich and poor, high income nation versus low income citizen, the Malaysia's hollow economy conundrum and addresses issue on the foreign workers, education and healthcare. It also explains the concept of free trade, its pros and cons .<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title='Rich Malaysia, Poor Malaysians' shows the economic reality

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: On education, the book advocates revisiting the national education philosophy, the introduction of the Love Pedagogy, promoting reading and critical thinking culture, the introduction of philosophy. It also touches on volunteerism and how the third party can become an agent of democracy.<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title=Malaysia's spectacular drop in inequality – for real?

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The book also offers insightful proposals and shares a way out for the problems facing the country.

The book was a bestseller for more than six months at Kinokuniya and Borders and is arguably a tour de force in the local intellectual landscape, as a venue for ideas that bridge policies and the hopes of the people, the responsibility of educators and the potential of their students and more important the problems of the present and the potential of a brighter future.<ref>{{cite news

date=November 2016}}: Tan Sri Arshad Ayub]], Father of UiTM and former deputy of Malaysia's Bank Negara launched the new and expanded edition of Rich Malaysia, Poor Malaysians. He was accompanied by [[Anuwar Ali
column3: Emeritus Professor Tan Sri Anuwar Ali]], Former Vice-Chancellor of Open University Malaysia and Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Tan Sri Dato' Ahmad Fuzi Abdul Razak, Secretary-General of the World Islamic Economic Forum and [[Ghauth Jasmon
column4: Professor Tan Sri Dr. Ghauth Jasmon]], former Vice-Chancellor of Universiti Malaya.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Tan Sri Arshad Ayub highlighted that Malaysia's 60th year of independence is the precise moment that Malaysia is to return to the drawing board. He argued that Anas has initiated the process by bringing forward a multitude of original ideas encompassing energy, economy, and education based on his analysis on the state of the nation and he urged the government, politicians, the civil society, and policy makers to take heed of Anas' powerfully brave book.<ref name=\"thehindu\">{{cite news
column4: title=Malaysia a success story, says former Bank Negara deputy governor

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The expanded book is an updated version with 13 additional chapters providing a more holistic coverage on fundamental issues that are currently plaguing Malaysia on healthcare, the foreign workers, environment, the hollow economy, green technology, woman empowerment and others.
Anas is a co-founder of BLINDSPOT,<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title=Malaysia's Vicious Inequality and Proposed Actions To Remedy It
column4: work=Malaysian Trades Union Congress}}</ref> a socio-economic think tank, a group of concerned citizens voicing out the voice of the voiceless - presenting critical, informative data and facts often missed.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Details of TPPA in a month - Nation {{!}} The Star Online

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Anas was formerly a Founding Chief Executive Officer on the board of Teach for The Needs (TFTN),<ref>{{cite news
column5: date=2 August 2013}}</ref> a non-profit education-based civil society organisation<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Malaysian Education Blueprint 2013-2025: A lacklustre framework - The Rakyat Post
column9: date=21 April 2014}}</ref> which houses 1,000 volunteers, 300 university students and adopts 12 orphanages.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: In 2013, Astro Awani named Anas as Top Ten social media influencers.<ref>{{cite news
date=November 2016}}: title=2013 10 personaliti media sosial paling berpengaruh
column4: work=www.astroawani.com}}</ref> That same year, The Malaysian Insider named Anas through Teach For The Needs (TFTN) as Inspiring person of the year.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=In the race for straight As, a movement teaches kids the most important values
column6: url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/race-straight-movement-teaches-kids-most-important-values-025806756.html?pt=tAD3SCT8P7}}</ref> Since his rise to fame, Anas has been giving public talks and forum nationwide on various topics and issues while remaining as a non political industry professional.

date=November 2016}}: office              = Member of the [[Senate of Pakistan]]
office1             = Member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]]

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Muhammad Hamza''' is a Pakistani politician who was a member of [[Senate of Pakistan]] from March 2012 to March 2018 and member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] between 1985 and 1999. He had been a member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly from 1962 to 1969. Hamza has served twice as the Chairman of [[Public Accounts Committee]]. He is known in Pakistani politics for his neutral views and as one of the closest aides of [[Fatima Jinnah]], the sister of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah
date=November 2016}}: Mohammad Ali Jinnah]], the founding father of the Nation.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He has done Master of Arts in Economics from the [[University of the Punjab]] in 1951.<ref>{{cite web
Hamza was born on 20th March,1929 in Ludhiana, Indian Punjab. His father Moulvi Abdullah was a prominent figure among Muslims in India.
He received his early education from Islamia School in Wait Ganj. Before partition he used to live in Muhalla Dholewal on Brown Road in Ludhiana.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Emotional home coming for Pakistan MP Hamza Ludhianvi {{!}} Ludhiana News - Times of India
column11: first3=17:04}}</ref> He migrated to Pakistan during his final year of Bachelor's. In Punjab, Government College, Lahore, used to be the number one college while the Government College for Boys, Ludhiana, used to be the next in those days. He pursued BA economics in Ludhiana, but completed the third year in Pakistan after Partition.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=Time flies, but memories are there forever

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: During his visit to Ludhiana in 2015, he expressed his love for the place where he was born. Reciting the verse of great Persian poet Sheikh Saadi he said, \"A place where a person is born is better for him than being the ruler of Egypt.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Emotional home coming for Pakistan MP Hamza Ludhianvi {{!}} Ludhiana News - Times of India
column11: first3=17:04}}</ref> He migrated to his hometown of [[Gojra Tehsil

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He has done Master of Arts in Economics from the [[University of the Punjab]] in 1951.<ref>{{cite web

M. Hamza is known for his neutral views in Pakistani politics. He remained vocal on political issues for almost five decades. He was one of a few West Pakistan Assembly members who were very much vocal against military dictator General [[Ayub Khan (general)
date=November 2016}}: Ayub Khan]] on assembly floor. He as MNA remained critic of his own Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] but when [[Pervez Musharraf
column3: Pervaiz Musharraf]] removed Nawaz Sharif, Hamza stood by him in his bad days.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He was a member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly from Lyallpur-VI Constituency from 1962 to 1965<ref>{{cite web
date=November 2016}}: title=Members of the West Pakistan Fifth Legislator
column7: language=en}}</ref> and again from 1965 to 1969.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Members of the West Pakistan Sixth Legislator
column11: publisher=Punjab Assembly}}</ref> During his tenure as member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly, he was very vocal against then President of Pakistan, [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)
column13: title=Hamza to retire from Senate in March
column17: date=2 February 2018}}</ref> He was one of the three opposition members who were elected from the ticket of Muslim League led by Fatima Jinnah. Toba Tek Singh was the only city other than Karachi where Fatima Jinnah's Muslim League won a seat, and Hamza became the member of parliament. Hamza used to held public protests across the country during the [[1968 movement in Pakistan
column18: 1968 Movement in Pakistan]] against military regime of Ayub Khan and was taken into custody in numerous occasions. President Ayub Khan resigned in the face of growing public protests, and was succeeded by General Yahya Khan. He stood against the Marshal Law of General Yahya Khan and was frontline leader for the civil democracy in Pakistan.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He was a very fierce opposition to the ruling party of Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto in the 70's. Hamza was amongst the prominent leaders of [[Pakistan National Alliance]] (PNA), a nine party coalition against the ruling party of [[Pakistan Peoples Party
date=November 2016}}: PPP]]. The protests of 1977 called for overthrow, [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Hamza’s was the only voice of opposition in the parliament the day when 295-C was passed immediately. During his speech in 1986, Hamza argued that the Islamic texts being cited by those advocating for the death penalty needed to be comprehensively reviewed by religious scholars before any change in the law could be passed. He claimed parliament was being irresponsible by avoiding a deeper debate on the issue. “I have a firm opinion,” said Hamza, “you cannot run the country on selective justice. What is the purpose of the law if it’s destructive for the society? Our people lack depth, they are unreasonably emotional about religion, so I knew that the law will be misused - that’s why I am opposing.”<ref>{{Cite web

He ran for the seat of the National Assembly as a candidate of [[Islami Jamhoori Ittehad]] (IJI) from Constituency NA-73 (Toba Tek Singh-III) in [[1988 Pakistani general election]] but was unsuccessful. He received 52,137 votes and lost the seat to Haji Muhammad Ishaq, a candidate of [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP).<ref name=\"ecp/na-88-97\">{{cite web
column8: url-status=live }}</ref>He remained highly critic of then Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He was re-elected to the National Assembly as a candidate of IJI from Constituency NA-73 (Toba Tek Singh-III) in [[1990 Pakistani general election]]. He received 69,499 votes and defeated Haji Muhammad Ishaq, a candidate of [[Pakistan Democratic Alliance]] (PDA).<ref name=\"ecp/na-88-97\" /> He was the appointed as the Chairman of Public Accounts Committee and remained very vocal against the corruption of former ruling party. He was considered a trustworthy and close aide to PM Nawaz Sharif.

He was re-elected to the National Assembly as a candidate of [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)]] (PML-N) from Constituency NA-73 (Toba Tek Singh-III) in [[1993 Pakistani general election]]. He received 48,419 votes and defeated Haji Muhammad Ishaq, a candidate of PPP.<ref name=\"ecp/na-88-97\" />

He was re-elected to the National Assembly as a candidate of PML-N from Constituency NA-73 (Toba Tek Singh-III) in [[1997 Pakistani general election]]. He received 43,931 votes and defeated Amjad Ali Warraich, an independent candidate,<ref name=\"ecp/na-88-97\" />and became the Chairman of Public Accounts Committee for the second term.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>During his second tenure as member of the National Assembly, he remained a critic of Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]].<ref name=\"nation/2feb20182\">{{cite news
column7: title=Hamza to retire from Senate in March
column10: accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref> He became close to Nawaz Sharif following the [[1999 Pakistani coup d'état]].<ref name=\"nation/2feb2018\" />He was among the notable leaders who resisted the Emergency imposed by the Army Chief General Musharraf.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He ran for the seat of the National Assembly as a candidate of PML-N from Constituency NA-92 (Toba Tek Singh-I) in [[2002 Pakistani general election]] but was unsuccessful. He received 51,416 votes and lost the seat to Amjad Ali Warraich, a candidate of [[Pakistan Muslim League (J)]].<ref>{{cite web

He ran for the seat of the National Assembly as a candidate of PML-N from Constituency NA-92 (Toba Tek Singh-I) in [[2008 Pakistani general election]] but was unsuccessful. He received 57,203 votes and lost the seat to [[Farkhanda Amjad]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: url-status=live }}</ref>Despite losing his seat, Hamza remained active in politics and was a central figure of opposition party [[PMLN]]. He took active participation in [[Lawyers' Movement
column9: Lawyers Movement]] and spent 5 days in Dera Ghazi Khan jail at the age of 79.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Muhammad Hamza''' is a Pakistani politician who was a member of [[Senate of Pakistan]] from March 2012 to March 2018 and member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] between 1985 and 1999. He had been a member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly from 1962 to 1969. Hamza has served twice as the Chairman of [[Public Accounts Committee]]. He is known in Pakistani politics for his neutral views and as one of the closest aides of [[Fatima Jinnah]], the sister of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah
date=November 2016}}: Mohammad Ali Jinnah]], the founding father of the Nation.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He has done Master of Arts in Economics from the [[University of the Punjab]] in 1951.<ref>{{cite web
Hamza was born on 20th March,1929 in Ludhiana, Indian Punjab. His father Moulvi Abdullah was a prominent figure among Muslims in India.
He received his early education from Islamia School in Wait Ganj. Before partition he used to live in Muhalla Dholewal on Brown Road in Ludhiana.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Emotional home coming for Pakistan MP Hamza Ludhianvi {{!}} Ludhiana News - Times of India
column11: first3=17:04}}</ref> He migrated to Pakistan during his final year of Bachelor's. In Punjab, Government College, Lahore, used to be the number one college while the Government College for Boys, Ludhiana, used to be the next in those days. He pursued BA economics in Ludhiana, but completed the third year in Pakistan after Partition.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=Time flies, but memories are there forever

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: During his visit to Ludhiana in 2015, he expressed his love for the place where he was born. Reciting the verse of great Persian poet Sheikh Saadi he said, \"A place where a person is born is better for him than being the ruler of Egypt.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Emotional home coming for Pakistan MP Hamza Ludhianvi {{!}} Ludhiana News - Times of India
column11: first3=17:04}}</ref> He migrated to his hometown of [[Gojra Tehsil

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He has done Master of Arts in Economics from the [[University of the Punjab]] in 1951.<ref>{{cite web

M. Hamza is known for his neutral views in Pakistani politics. He remained vocal on political issues for almost five decades. He was one of a few West Pakistan Assembly members who were very much vocal against military dictator General [[Ayub Khan (general)
date=November 2016}}: Ayub Khan]] on assembly floor. He as MNA remained critic of his own Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] but when [[Pervez Musharraf
column3: Pervaiz Musharraf]] removed Nawaz Sharif, Hamza stood by him in his bad days.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: He was a member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly from Lyallpur-VI Constituency from 1962 to 1965<ref>{{cite web
date=November 2016}}: title=Members of the West Pakistan Fifth Legislator
column7: language=en}}</ref> and again from 1965 to 1969.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Members of the West Pakistan Sixth Legislator
column11: publisher=Punjab Assembly}}</ref> During his tenure as member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly, he was very vocal against then President of Pakistan, [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)
column13: title=Hamza to retire from Senate in March
column17: date=2 February 2018}}</ref> He was one of the three opposition members who were elected from the ticket of Muslim League led by Fatima Jinnah. Toba Tek Singh was the only city other than Karachi where Fatima Jinnah's Muslim League won a seat, and Hamza became the member of parliament. Hamza used to held public protests across the country during the [[1968 movement in Pakistan
column18: 1968 Movement in Pakistan]] against military regime of Ayub Khan and was taken into custody in numerous occasions. President Ayub Khan resigned in the face of growing public protests, and was succeeded by General Yahya Khan. He stood against the Marshal Law of General Yahya Khan and was frontline leader for the civil democracy in Pakistan.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Kelty Hearts Football Club''' are a [[Association football
date=November 2016}}: football]] club based in the village of [[Kelty]] in [[Fife]], [[Scotland]]. Formed in 1975<ref name=\"History\"/> and nicknamed ''the Hearts'' and ''the Jambos'', they play their home games at New Central Park.<ref name=\"New Central Park\"/> Their home strip  colours are maroon, with white shorts and maroon socks, while their away strip colours are blue, with blue shorts and blue socks.

2018–19 season]] Kelty Hearts competed in the [[Lowland League]], the fifth tier of the [[Scottish football league system]], having been promoted from the [[East of Scotland Football League]].<ref>{{cite tweet
column9: title=Kelty Hearts continue perfect East of Scotland League record at Leith Athletic
column14: title=Kelty Hearts eye SPFL as they close in on debut season title with 100% record
column20: accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> The club were previously members of the Fife Junior League and the [[Scottish Junior Football East Region Super League
column21: SJFA East Superleague]], which is the highest division of the [[Scottish Junior Football Association, East Region
column22: East Region]] of the [[Scottish Junior Football Association]].

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: In December 2017 the club became a full [[Scottish Football Association
date=November 2016}}: SFA]] member, making them eligible to enter the [[Scottish Cup]] and move up through the senior divisions.<ref name=\":0\">{{cite web

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The team had been managed since October 2013 by [[Tam Courts]] but the club reluctantly accepted his resignation as manager on 11 October 2018.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Kelty Hearts Football Club on Twitter
Scotland]] captain [[Barry Ferguson]] was announced as the club's new manager on 18 October 2018.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Rangers legend Barry Ferguson agrees deal to join Kelty Hearts as manager

date=November 2016}}: 2019-20]] Lowland League was ended with immediate effect on 13 April 2020 due to the [[Coronavirus disease 2019
column3: COVID-19]] pandemic with Kelty Hearts being declared champions on a points ger game average based on the current standings.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Kelty Hearts named champions as Lowland League called early
column11: title=Season Ends With Immediate Effect - Kelty Hearts crowned as champions

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Kelty Hearts play their home games at New Central Park, situated just off Bath Street in [[Kelty]].
The overall capacity of New Central Park is 2,181 and consists of two covered enclosures which can hold around 1,030 spectators in total and a seated stand with a capacity of 353.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> There is a social club and a sports bar within the ground. The pitch at New Central Park has a 3G MX artificial surface, which was installed in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web

date=November 2016}}: Dunfermline Athletic]] Reserves also play their home games at New Central Park.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Scotland - Dunfermline Athletic FC Reserves - Results, fixtures, squad, statistics, photos, videos and news - Soccerway

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The majority of supporters of Kelty Hearts come from the village of [[Kelty]] and surrounding areas in [[Fife]].
Kelty are also known to attract many [[Groundhopping
date=November 2016}}: groundhoppers]] due to the club's good reputation as hosts on matchdays.<ref>{{Cite web

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Kelty share a fierce local rivalry with [[East of Scotland Football League
date=November 2016}}: East of Scotland]] team [[Hill of Beath Hawthorn F.C.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Both clubs were founded in the same year in 1975. The rivalry mainly stems from the close proximity of the two clubs and both being very successful [[Scottish Junior Football Association
date=November 2016}}: junior]] sides within the Fife League. Kelty and [[Hill of Beath Hawthorn F.C.
column3: Hill of Beath]] would often exchange Fife league title wins from year to year, also frequently meet in cup competitions.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Hearts and Haws set for Junior Cup cracker

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Kelty Hearts are currently in the league above [[Hill of Beath Hawthorn F.C.
date=November 2016}}: Hill of Beath]], competing in the [[Lowland Football League
column3: Lowland League]]. However, they can still face each other in some cup competitions.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Kelty's other rivals include [[Linlithgow Rose F.C.
date=November 2016}}: Linlithgow Rose]], another successful former [[Scottish Junior Football Association, East Region
column3: East junior]] side, who they have faced in both league and cup competitions.<ref name=\":1\" />

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: A lot of [[Scottish Junior Football Association, West Region
date=November 2016}}: West junior]] teams had considered Kelty competitive rivals due to the clubs success in the [[Scottish Junior Football Association, East Region
column3: East]] and meeting several times in the [[Scottish Junior Cup]].<ref>{{Cite web

column22: Preliminary Round 1, losing to [[Lothian Thistle Hutchison Vale F.C.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: [[East of Scotland Football League]]<ref name=\"hons\">{{cite web
[[Scottish Junior Football East Region Super League
[[Scottish Junior Football East Region Premier League
date=November 2016}}: SJFA East Region Premier League]]<ref name=\"hons\" />

[[LeAnn Rimes]]

arranger]], manager and [[record producer]] who has collaborated with recording artists and contributed music to the film and television industries. Brown maintains residences in both Los Angeles, United States (US), and [[Nashville]], US.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=The Opinion Pages : Measure For Measure : Darrell Brown

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown has been credited with worldwide music sales of over seventy seven million units, as both a songwriter and producer.<ref>{{cite web

Brown co-wrote the number 1 hit \"[[You'll Think of Me]]” by [[Keith Urban]], which won the [[Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance]] in 2006. Brown also co-wrote Urban's smash hit \"[[Raining on Sunday]]\".
Brown's co-written the hit single for [[Josh Turner]], \"[[Why Don't We Just Dance]]\", was Number #1 on the ''Billboard'' Country Charts for four weeks in a row.<ref>{{cite web
date=November 2016}}: title=ASCAP, BMI Honor Josh Turner, Writers of \"Why Don't We Just Dance\"
column8: date=24 March 2010}}</ref> The longest running number 1 single of Josh Turner's career and Turner's first Number 1 single on the Canadian Country Charts. \"Why Don't We Just Dance\" was the Most Played Country Single of The Year in 2010 according to [[Mediabase]].

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: [[John Mayer]] and [[Keith Urban]] recently performed one of Darrell's songs \"If Ever I Could Love” on a newly filmed Country Music Television (CMT) Crossroads Television Special for CMT and Brown's songs \"[[Good Friend and a Glass of Wine]]” and \"[[Nothin' Better to Do]]” were performed by [[Joss Stone]] and LeAnn Rimes on last Year's Crossroad's CMT Special.

Brown co-arranged and worked on  [[Neil Young]] latest release \"Earth\".  As well as on  [[Neil Young and Crazy Horse]] 2012 release, ''Americana'', and arranged and conducted a one hundred-voice choir on [[Neil Young
date=November 2016}}: Neil Young's]] ''[[Living with War]]''; Brown also worked on Young's ''Chrome Dreams 2'' album.
David Gray]] and [[LeAnn Rimes]] duet \"Snow In Vegas\", that was featured on David Gray's \"Mutineers\" Deluxe version of his Album.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown co-produced and arranged the [[Blush (Asian band)
date=November 2016}}: Blush]] single, \"Undivided\" (featuring [[Snoop Dogg]]), a release that reached the \"#2\" position on the \"''[[Billboard (magazine)
column3: Billboard]]'' Dance\" music chart. Their follow up  single \"Dance On\" reached the # 1 position on \"''[[Billboard (magazine)

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown produced and arranged the critically acclaimed cult record Radney Foster's, \"See What You Want To See\" on Arista Austin Records. The Dixie Chicks, Keith Urban, Dierks Bentley, Darius Rucker and a host of other artists and songwriters hail this recording as one of Foster's best and has influenced the cutting edge of Nashville over the last decade and a half. Songs Raining On Sunday, Godspeed, I'm In among others originally appeared on this recording.

In partnership with Fletcher Foster, Brown is co-executive producer for the series of 2012 remixes that adapted Tammy Wynette's \"Stand By Your Man\" single. The first remix was released on June 5, 2012, opening a year-long celebration of the Tammy Wynette \"Legacy\".
Brown also produced and co-wrote the #1 pop single for Jim Brickman and Rebecca Lyn Howard, \"Simple Things.\"
Brown spearheaded the Epic Records passion project \"Soul Mission,\" co-writing and producing for the super group, which included [[Steve Cropper]], [[Mavis Staples]] and [[Booker T. Jones]].

Brown's other productions include  [[Radney Foster]] \"This World We Live in\" and \" Revival\", [[Ty Herndon]] \"Right About Now\", [[First Call]] \"Sacred Journey\", [[Michelle Shocked]] \"Good News\",  [[Deborah Lippmann]] \" Vinyl\" and \"Christmas EP\" among others.
Brown is the co-producer, arranger and co-writer for 2017 (USA) and 2016 (Uk) release of [[LeAnn Rimes]] album, ''[[Remnants (LeAnn Rimes album)

Remnants continues to garner critical acclaim alongside her prior \"Spitfire\" Project.  With highlights being the title track \"Remnants\", for the emotional rawness of \"Mother\",  for the soulfulness of \"Do It Wrong With Me\" and \"Love is Love is Love\" and for her first USA Hot AC single release off of Remnants is  [[Long Live Love (LeAnn Rimes song)
date=November 2016}}: Long Live Love]]. Her dance remix of \"Long Live Love\" reached #1 on the Billboard Dance Club Charts with remixers Dave Aude, Ivan Gomez, DrewG and Dj Deville bringing their talents from the turntables to the dance floor. [[Mark Batson]] came aboard as co-producer and co-writer for most of the album, with Steve Jordan co -producing one track as well.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown was also the producer, arranger and main co-writer for the 2013 [[LeAnn Rimes]] album, ''[[Spitfire (LeAnn Rimes album)
date=November 2016}}: Spitfire]]'', the recording artist's last contractual record with [[Curb Records]]. Spitfire was another critically acclaimed please for Rimes. With almost every major publication stating she so far has created the best album of her career. With Alison Krauss, Jeff Beck, Rob Thomas among others joining her on tracks \"What Have I Done\", \"Gasoline and Matches\" and \"Borrowed\".

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Previously, Brown has co-written with LeAnn Rimes nine songs for her critically acclaimed release ''[[Family (LeAnn Rimes album)
date=November 2016}}: Family]]'' - which includes her multi-format hit single \"Nothin' Better to Do\",  a career charting single, the first in history making its way onto the Country Singles chart, the A/C chart and the Club play Dance Chart at the same time. \"[[What I Cannot Change]]\" hit number # 1 on The Billboard Dance Charts\".

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown also co-produced (with [[Vince Gill]]) the LeAnn Rimes album, ''[[Lady & Gentlemen]]'', and the singles, \"[[Crazy Women]]\" and \"[[Give (song)

Brown also co-produced Rimes on the track \"Smokin' In The Boys Room\" for the '''''Nashville Outlaws: A Tribute to Mötley Crüe'''''  a 2014 studio album released via [[Big Machine Records]]. It is a [[tribute album]] to the [[heavy metal music
date=November 2016}}: heavy metal]] band [[Mötley Crüe]], featuring covers of their songs performed by various [[country music]] artists.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown executive produced Rimes Greatest Hits Dance Remix Collection titled \"Dance Like You Don't Give A ....\" on Curb Records. The Collection of mostly newly remixed greatest hits went Number 1 on the iTunes Dance Charts on its first days of release.

Brown was contributed songs and music to films such as Steven Soderbergh's next film \"Logan Lucky\", for Coen Brothers  \"Gambit\", \"My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2, \"Cruel Intentions\" among others over the years.
Brown co-wrote and co-produced with [[Nathan Chapman (record producer)
date=November 2016}}: Nathan Chapman]] and [[Rita Wilson]] the end title song \"Even More Mine\" for the movie, \"Big Fat Greek Wedding 2\".

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown co-wrote with [[LeAnn Rimes]] and co-produced with [[Dave Aude]] three new Holiday songs for 2018 Hallmark Channel's Christmas Movie \"It's Christmas,Eve\" All songs are included on the soundtrack for the movie available on EverLE Records / Thirty Tigers.
Brown co-wrote and produced songs with Robby Armstrong for the [[Michael Hoffman (American director)
column9: author=Terri Quinlan}}</ref>  starring [[Cameron Diaz]], [[Colin Firth]], and [[Alan Rickman]], with a script by the [[Coen brothers]].

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Brown has also written and produced music that has appeared in both film and television; the former includes productions such as Gambit, ''[[Like Dandelion Dust]]'', and ''Cruel Intentions'', while television series ''[[Cold Case (TV series)
date=November 2016}}: Cold Case]]'', ''[[Rookie Blue]]'', ''One Tree Hill'', ''[[Angela's Eyes]]'', ''[[Las Vegas (TV series)
column3: Las Vegas]]'', and ''Man of the People'' have utilized Brown's musical work.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Since 2014 Brown plays himself in [[LeAnn Rimes]] and [[Eddie Cibrian]]'s TV Reality show \"LeAnn & Eddie\" on [[VH1]].

Brown is responsible for the creation and production of specific rock, pop and country music that has been written and designed for the internationally renowned hit EA video game franchise [[The Sims]], [[The Sims 3]] and for underscore music for other video games for EA and EA sports that include [[Nintendo Wii]] Boogie and Playground.
Brown completed production on EA Sims 3 Video game expansion pack producing Simlish vocals on [[Martina McBride]], [[Luke Bryan]], [[Lady Antebellum]], [[Thompson Square]] and [[The Lunabelles]].

Brown and Rimes co-authored a tome based on the song \"What I Cannot Change\" for Harper Studio Book Publishers, based on the letters received from people around the world who were moved and inspired by the song.

Brown currently serves on the Board of Trustees for NARAS. Brown served as musical director and co-creative producer for the Grammy Preservation and Legacy concerts that occurred every year during Grammy week leading up to the Grammy Awards. Brown has worked as MD for many Grammy Events around the country working with Solomon Burke, Ed Sheeran, Natasha Bedingfield, Dionne Warrick, Jason Mraz, Emmy Lou Harris and Rodney Crowell, Ledisi, Yolanda Adams, Christette Michele, Lupe Fiasco, The Fray, Lianne Van Havas, Guy Sebastion, Musiq Soulchild, Jeff Beck, Melanie Fiona, Jerry Lee Lewis, John Fogerty, BeBe Winans, Joe Nichols, Colby Callait, Sarah Barrellis, The Fray, Trombone Shorty, Mavis Staples, Dave Koz, Shelby Lynn, Robert Cray, Martina Mcbride, Garth Brooks, Kid Rock, Gretchen Wilson, Loretta Lynn, Jonny Lang, Bret Michaels, Lee Ann Womack, Jimmy Webb, JD Souther, Dan Wilson, Joy Williams, Johnny Rzeznik, Jeff Barry, Allen Shamblin, Mike Reid, Bonnie Raitt, Kris Kristofferson, Steve Cropper, Valerie Simpson, Skylar Grey, Gavin Degraw, Aloe Blacc, Melissa Etheridge,
Plain White T's, Walk The Moon, Deborah Cox, Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp, Erica McDonald among many others.
\"A Waste Is A Terrible Thing To Mind\"
\"Good Friend and a Glass of Wine\"
Simple Things w/ Rebecca Lyn Howard
\"In The Arms Of The One Who Loves Me\"
\"If I Could Only Have Her Love Back\"
\"The Day That I Stop Loving You\"
\"Once Upon a Time\" (''[[Moment of Truth (Terri Nunn album)
\"Too Far to Fall\" (''Moment of Truth'' album, 1991)

date=November 2016}}: caption = Chenault and his wife at [[President Barack Obama]]'s second [[state dinner]]

column8: title=American Express Lifts Chenault's Pay 19% to $22 Million for '16

date=November 2016}}: occupation = Former CEO of [[American Express]]<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=American Express CEO Ken Chenault: 'There's a $25 trillion opportunity'
column8: title=An interview with Kenneth Chenault, CEO at American Express

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Kenneth Irvine Chenault''' (born June 2, 1951) is an American business executive. He was the [[CEO]] and [[Chairman]] of [[American Express]] from 2001 until 2018.<ref name=\"ae\">{{cite web
column3: title=Board of Directors and Executive Officers
column12: publisher=[[Forbes]]}}</ref>  He is the third African American CEO of a [[Fortune 500]] company.<ref>{{Cite news
column14: title=There Are Currently 4 Black CEOs in the Fortune. 500

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Chenault was born in [[Mineola, New York]], Nassau County, the son of a dentist and dental hygienist.<ref name=\"biography.com\">{{cite web
column6: title=Kenneth Chenault Biography – Facts, Birthday, Life Story
column9: accessdate=2012-03-20 }}</ref> His father, Hortenius Chenault, was a graduate of [[Morehouse College]] and [[Howard University]] Dental School. The elder Chenault passed the [[New York (state)
column10: New York]] State dental exam with the highest score ever recorded as of January 2014.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Chenault, Hortenius · Notable Kentucky African Americans Database
column14: access-date=2019-08-13}}</ref> Chenault was a member of [[Phi Beta Sigma]] fraternity. Kenneth Chenault attended the [[Waldorf education
column15: Waldorf School]] of [[Garden City, New York
column16: Garden City]],<ref> lived in the incorporated village of hempstead .[http://www.businessweek.com/1998/51/b3609001.htm \"Ken Chenault: The Rise of a Star\"] ''Business Week'' Dec. 21, 1998</ref> where he served as senior class president.<ref name=\"biography.com\"/> He then received a [[Bachelor of Arts
column17: B.A.]] in [[history]] from [[Bowdoin College]] in 1973 and a [[Juris Doctor

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Chenault began his career as an associate at the law firm [[Rogers & Wells]] (1977–1979) in [[New York City]], and as a consultant for [[Bain & Company]] (1979–1981).<ref name=\"cnn\"/><ref>{{cite web
Chenault joined American Express in 1981, working in its Strategic Planning Group.<ref name=\"bw\">

column3: title=KEN CHENAULT: THE RISE OF A STAR

date=November 2016}}: president]] and [[chief operating officer]] in 1997.<ref name=\"bw\"/> He became CEO of American Express in 2001.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=American Express CEO Ken Chenault to leave after 17-year run

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Chenault has served on several boards throughout his career. Beginning in 2007, he served on the Executive Committee of the [[Business Roundtable]]<ref name=\"br\">{{cite web
column11: access-date=2019-11-18}}</ref> and a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]].<ref>See for example the transcript of a luncheon over which he presided: {{cite web
column13: title=New Realities in the Media Age: A Conversation with Donald Rumsfeld
column19: archivedate=August 10, 2008 }}</ref> Chenault served as a member of the Executive Committee of [[The Business Council]] in 2011 and 2012.<ref name=\"committee\">[http://www.thebusinesscouncil.org/about/excommittee.aspx The Business Council, Official website, Executive Committee] {{webarchive

date=November 2016}}: Ebony]]'' listed him as one of 50 \"living pioneers\" in the African-American community.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=50 who changed America – influential African Americans
column11: archivedate=2007-07-02 }}</ref>  Chenault was inducted into the Junior Achievement U.S. Business Hall of Fame in 2002.  In 2008, he gave the commencement address at [[Howard University]].<ref>{{cite web

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: In May 2010, he gave the [[commencement speech]] at [[Wake Forest University]]<ref>[http://www.wfu.edu/wowf/2010/20100322.commencement.php American Express CEO to deliver address], ''Window on Wake Forest'', March 22, 2010. Accessed 2010-03-22.</ref> and [[Northeastern University]].<ref>[http://www.northeastern.edu/news/stories/2010/03/chenault.html May commencement speakers announced] {{webarchive

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: [[Category:American chief executives of financial services companies]]

'''Japanese folktales ''' are an important cultural aspect of Japan. In commonplace usage, they signify a certain set of well-known classic tales, with a vague distinction of whether they fit the rigorous definition of \"[[Oral tradition
date=November 2016}}: folktale]]\" or not among various types of [[folklore]]. The admixed imposters are literate written pieces, dating back to the [[Muromachi period]] (14th-16th centuries) or even earlier times in the Middle Ages. These would not normally qualify as \"folktales\" (i.e., pieces collected from oral tradition among the populace).

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: In a more stringent sense, \"Japanese folktales\" refer to orally transmitted folk narrative. Systematic collection of specimens was pioneered by folklorist [[Kunio Yanagita]]. Yanagita disliked the word '''{{Nihongo
column3: 民話}}''', a coined term directly translated from \"folktale\" (Yanagita stated that the term was not familiar to actual old folk he collected folktales from, and was not willing to \"go along\" with the conventions of other countries<ref>Yanagita, \"Preface to the 1960 edition\", appended to ''Nihon no mukashibanashi'' (Folk tales of Japan), Shinchosha, 1983, p.175.</ref>). He therefore proposed the use of the term {{Nihongo
column6: \"tales of long ago\"}} to apply to all creative types of folktales (i.e., those that are not \"legendary\" types which are more of a reportage).<ref name=heibonsha-minwa>{{Harvnb

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: A representative sampling of Japanese folklore would definitely include the quintessential '''''[[Momotarō]]''''' ('''Peach Boy'''), and perhaps other folktales listed among the so-called {{nihongo
column13: isbn=978-4-490-10033-4}}, p.198. quote:\"ごだいおとぎぱなし（五大御伽話）。五大昔話ともいう。桃太郎、猿蟹合戦、舌切雀、花咲爺、かちかち山の五話\"</ref> the battle between ''[[The Crab and the Monkey]]'', ''[[Shita-kiri Suzume]]'' (Tongue-cut sparrow), ''[[Hanasaka Jiisan]]'' (Flower-blooming old man), and ''[[Kachi-kachi Yama]]''.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: These stories just named are considered genuine folktales, having received those auspices by folklorist Kunio Yanagita.<ref>{{cite book
column10: url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g1Q0AQAAIAAJ}}, p.253, says calling them ''otogibanashi'' (see below) is a misnomer, since they are ''mukashi banashi'' (Yanagita's preferred term for folktales orally transmitted)</ref> During the [[Edo period]] these tales had been adapted by professional writers and woodblock-printed in a form a called ''[[kusazōshi]]'' (cf.[[chapbooks]]), but a number of local variant versions of the tales have been collected in the field as well.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: As a forestated, non-genuine folktales are those already committed to writing long ago, the earliest being the tale of Princess Kaguya (or ''[[The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter]]''), an example of [[monogatari]] type of romance dated to as early as the 10th century,<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=The Old Bamboo-Hewer's Story (Taketori no okina no monogatari): The earliest of the Japanese romances, written in the 10th century
column9: url=https://archive.org/details/oldbamboohewers00dickgoog}}</ref> though extant manuscripts are much later. The text gives reference, for example, to the flame-proof \"{{nihongo
column14: salamander]])'s fur robe\" (perhaps familiar to watchers of the anime ''[[Inuyasha]]'' as the vestment of the title character), which attests to considerable degree of book-knowledge and learning by its author.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Other examples of pseudo-folktales which have been composed in the Middle Ages are the ''[[Uji Shūi Monogatari]]'' (13th century) that includes the nucleus of classics as ([[Kobutori Jisan
date=November 2016}}: ''Kobutori Jīsan'']] - the old man with the hump on his cheek, and ''[[Straw Millionaire]]''). This and the ''[[Konjaku Monogatarishū]]'' (12th century) also contains a number of type of tales designated ''[[setsuwa]]'', a generic term for narratives of various nature, anything from moralizing to comical. Both works, it might be noted, are divided into parts containing tales from India, tales from China, and tales from Japan. In the ''Konjaku Monogatarishū'' can be seen the early developments of the [[Kintarō]] legend, familiar in folktale-type form.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The Japanese word used to correspond to \"folktale\" has undergone development over the years. From the [[Edo period]], the term used was {{Nihongo
column3: お伽話}}, i.e., tales told by the ''otogii-shū'' who were professional storytellers hired to entertain the daimyō lord at the bedside.<ref name=heibonsha-mukashibanashi>{{Harvnb
column5: 1969}}, encyclopedia, vol.21, 499-504, on mukashibanashi by Shizuka Yamamuro and Taizo Tanaka</ref> That term continued to be in currency through the [[Meiji era]] (late 19th century), when imported terms such as ''minwa'' began usage.<ref name=heibonsha-mukashibanashi/> In the [[Taishō era]], the word ''dōwa'' (lit. \"children's story\" but was a translated coinage for [[fairy tales]] or ''[[wikt:Märchen
column6: märchen]]'') was used.<ref name=heibonsha-mukashibanashi/> Then Yanagita popularized the use of ''mukashi-banashi'' \"tales of long ago\", as mentioned before.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Although some Japanese ghost stories or ''[[kaidan]]'' such as the story of the [[Yuki-onna]] (\"snow woman\") might be considered examples of folktales, but even though some overlaps may exist, they are usually treated as another genre. The familiar forms of stories are embellished works of literature by [[gesaku]] writers, or retooled for the [[kabuki]] theater performance, in the case of the [[bakeneko]] or monstrous cat. The famous collection ''[[Kwaidan]]'' by [[Lafcadio Hearn]] also consists of original retellings. Yanagita published a collection '{{nihongo
column5: Tohno Monogatari}}' (1910) which featured a number of fanatastical ''[[yōkai]]'' creatures such as [[Zashiki-warashi]] and [[kappa (folklore)

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: ''namidabanashi'', sad stories; ''obakebanashi'', ghost stories; ''ongaeshibanashi'', stories of repaying kindness; ''tonchibanashi'', witty stories; ''waraibanashi'', funny stories; and ''yokubaribanashi'', stories of greed. (These are not standard or commonplace terms or classifications, except perhaps warai banashi. Tonchi banashi is a term but perhaps not a category.)
In the middle years of the 20th century storytellers would often travel from town to town telling these stories with special paper illustrations called [[kamishibai]].
Below is a list of well-known Japanese folktales:

date=November 2016}}: the superhuman Golden Boy, based on folk hero Sakata no Kintoki
[[File:The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter - Discovery of Princess Kaguya.jpg
about a mysterious girl called Kaguya-hime who is said to be from the capital of the moon
a warrior and a dog who defeated evil spirits
the story of a teakettle which is actually a shape-changing tanuki
the story of the old man that made the flowers bloom
a [[Jizō]] statue given a straw hat and is grateful
the story of an old man who drops rice into a mouse hole
the story of the tongue-cut sparrow
who rescued a turtle and visited the bottom of the sea
a man with a large wen (tumor, kobu) on his cheek, and how he loses it
[[File:Rabbit's Triumph - climax of the Kachi-kachi Yama.markings of Ogata Gekko.detail - image for k-k y article.version 1.wittig collection - painting 22.png

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Tongue-cut sparrow''': A washer woman cut off the tongue of a sparrow that was pecking at her rice starch. The sparrow had been fed regularly by the washer woman's neighbors, so when the sparrow didn't come, they went in the woods to search for it. They found it, and after a feast and some dancing (which the sparrow prepared), the neighbors were given the choice between two boxes; one large and one small. The neighbors picked the small box, and it was filled with riches. The washer woman saw these riches and heard where they came from, so she went to the sparrow. She too was entertained and given the choice between two boxes. The washer woman picked the largest box and instead of gaining riches, she was devoured by devils.<ref name=piggott>Japanese Mythology: Library of the World's Myths and Legends, by Juliet Piggott</ref>

'''Mandarin Ducks''': A man kills a drake mandarin duck for food. That night he had a dream that a woman was accusing him of murdering her husband, and then told him to return to the lake. The man does this, and a female mandarin walks up to him and tears its chest open.<ref name=piggott/>

'''Tanuki and Rabbit''': A man catches a tanuki and tells his wife to cook it in a stew. The tanuki begs the wife not to cook him and promises to help with the cooking if he is spared. The wife agrees and unties him. The tanuki then transforms into her and kills her, then cooks her in a stew. Disguised as the man's wife, the tanuki feeds him his wife. Once he is done, the tanuki transforms back to his original form and teases the man for eating his wife. A rabbit that was friends with the family was furious, so he had the tanuki carry sticks and, while he wasn't looking, set these sticks on fire. Then the rabbit treated the burn with hot pepper paste. Finally, the rabbit convinced the tanuki to build a boat of clay, and the rabbit followed in a sturdy boat. The clay boat began to sink, so the tanuki tried to escape, but then the rabbit hit him in the head with an oar, knocking him out and making him drown.<ref name=piggott/>

'''Badger and Fox cub''': A badger, vixen, and the vixen's cub lived in a forest that was running out of food, so they came up with the plan of one of them pretending to be dead, the other disguising as a merchant, and the “merchant” selling the “dead” animal to a human. Then they would have money to buy food. The vixen pretended to be dead while the badger was the merchant. While the transaction was happening however, the badger told the human that the vixen wasn't actually dead, so the human killed her. This infuriated the cub, so he proposed a competition. They would both disguise as humans and go into the village at different times. Whoever guessed what “human” was the other first, wins. The cub walked towards the village first, but he hid behind a tree. The badger went into the village, and accused the governor of being the fox, so the bodyguards of the governor beheaded him.<ref name=piggott/>
The folklore of Japan has been influenced by foreign literature as well as the kind of [[spirit worship]] prevalent all throughout prehistoric Asia.
The monkey stories of Japanese folklore have been influenced both by the [[Sanskrit]] [[Indian epic poetry
column3: Chinese]] classic ''[[Journey to the West]]''.<ref>On the Road to Baghdad Or Traveling Biculturalism: Theorizing a Bicultural Approach to... By Gonul Pultar, ed., Gönül Pultar. Published 2005. New Academia Publishing, LLC. {{ISBN
column4: 0-9767042-1-8}}. Page 193</ref> The stories mentioned in the Buddhist [[Jataka]] tales appear in a modified form throughout the Japanese collection of popular stories.<ref>The Hindu World By Sushil Mittal. Published 2004. Routledge. {{ISBN
column5: 0-415-21527-7}}. pp93</ref><ref>Discovering the Arts of Japan: A Historical Overview By Tsuneko S. Sadao, Stephanie Wada. Published 2003. Kodansha International. {{ISBN

date=November 2016}}: ancient India]] were influential in shaping Japanese stories by providing them with materials. [[India]]n materials were greatly modified and adapted in such a way as would appeal to the sensibilities of common people of Japan in general, transmitted through China and Korea.<ref>Miraculous Stories from the Japanese Buddhist Tradition: The [[Nihon Ryōiki]] of the Monk Kyōkai By Kyōkai. Published 1997. Routledge. {{ISBN
column3: 0-7007-0449-3}}</ref><ref>The Sanskrit Epics By John L Brockington. Published 1998. Brill Academic Publishers. {{ISBN

These would not normally qualify as \"folktales\" (i.e., pieces collected from oral tradition among the populace).

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: In a more stringent sense, \"Japanese folktales\" refer to orally transmitted folk narrative. Systematic collection of specimens was pioneered by folklorist [[Kunio Yanagita]]. Yanagita disliked the word '''{{Nihongo
column3: 民話}}''', a coined term directly translated from \"folktale\" (Yanagita stated that the term was not familiar to actual old folk he collected folktales from, and was not willing to \"go along\" with the conventions of other countries<ref>Yanagita, \"Preface to the 1960 edition\", appended to ''Nihon no mukashibanashi'' (Folk tales of Japan), Shinchosha, 1983, p.175.</ref>). He therefore proposed the use of the term {{Nihongo
column6: \"tales of long ago\"}} to apply to all creative types of folktales (i.e., those that are not \"legendary\" types which are more of a reportage).<ref name=heibonsha-minwa>{{Harvnb

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: A representative sampling of Japanese folklore would definitely include the quintessential '''''[[Momotarō]]''''' ('''Peach Boy'''), and perhaps other folktales listed among the so-called {{nihongo
column13: isbn=978-4-490-10033-4}}, p.198. quote:\"ごだいおとぎぱなし（五大御伽話）。五大昔話ともいう。桃太郎、猿蟹合戦、舌切雀、花咲爺、かちかち山の五話\"</ref> the battle between ''[[The Crab and the Monkey]]'', ''[[Shita-kiri Suzume]]'' (Tongue-cut sparrow), ''[[Hanasaka Jiisan]]'' (Flower-blooming old man), and ''[[Kachi-kachi Yama]]''.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: These stories just named are considered genuine folktales, having received those auspices by folklorist Kunio Yanagita.<ref>{{cite book
column10: url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g1Q0AQAAIAAJ}}, p.253, says calling them ''otogibanashi'' (see below) is a misnomer, since they are ''mukashi banashi'' (Yanagita's preferred term for folktales orally transmitted)</ref> During the [[Edo period]] these tales had been adapted by professional writers and woodblock-printed in a form a called ''[[kusazōshi]]'' (cf.[[chapbooks]]), but a number of local variant versions of the tales have been collected in the field as well.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: As a forestated, non-genuine folktales are those already committed to writing long ago, the earliest being the tale of Princess Kaguya (or ''[[The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter]]''), an example of [[monogatari]] type of romance dated to as early as the 10th century,<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=The Old Bamboo-Hewer's Story (Taketori no okina no monogatari): The earliest of the Japanese romances, written in the 10th century
column9: url=https://archive.org/details/oldbamboohewers00dickgoog}}</ref> though extant manuscripts are much later. The text gives reference, for example, to the flame-proof \"{{nihongo
column14: salamander]])'s fur robe\" (perhaps familiar to watchers of the anime ''[[Inuyasha]]'' as the vestment of the title character), which attests to considerable degree of book-knowledge and learning by its author.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Other examples of pseudo-folktales which have been composed in the Middle Ages are the ''[[Uji Shūi Monogatari]]'' (13th century) that includes the nucleus of classics as ([[Kobutori Jisan
date=November 2016}}: ''Kobutori Jīsan'']] - the old man with the hump on his cheek, and ''[[Straw Millionaire]]''). This and the ''[[Konjaku Monogatarishū]]'' (12th century) also contains a number of type of tales designated ''[[setsuwa]]'', a generic term for narratives of various nature, anything from moralizing to comical. Both works, it might be noted, are divided into parts containing tales from India, tales from China, and tales from Japan. In the ''Konjaku Monogatarishū'' can be seen the early developments of the [[Kintarō]] legend, familiar in folktale-type form.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The Japanese word used to correspond to \"folktale\" has undergone development over the years. From the [[Edo period]], the term used was {{Nihongo
column3: お伽話}}, i.e., tales told by the ''otogii-shū'' who were professional storytellers hired to entertain the daimyō lord at the bedside.<ref name=heibonsha-mukashibanashi>{{Harvnb
column5: 1969}}, encyclopedia, vol.21, 499-504, on mukashibanashi by Shizuka Yamamuro and Taizo Tanaka</ref> That term continued to be in currency through the [[Meiji era]] (late 19th century), when imported terms such as ''minwa'' began usage.<ref name=heibonsha-mukashibanashi/> In the [[Taishō era]], the word ''dōwa'' (lit. \"children's story\" but was a translated coinage for [[fairy tales]] or ''[[wikt:Märchen
column6: märchen]]'') was used.<ref name=heibonsha-mukashibanashi/> Then Yanagita popularized the use of ''mukashi-banashi'' \"tales of long ago\", as mentioned before.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Although some Japanese ghost stories or ''[[kaidan]]'' such as the story of the [[Yuki-onna]] (\"snow woman\") might be considered examples of folktales, but even though some overlaps may exist, they are usually treated as another genre. The familiar forms of stories are embellished works of literature by [[gesaku]] writers, or retooled for the [[kabuki]] theater performance, in the case of the [[bakeneko]] or monstrous cat. The famous collection ''[[Kwaidan]]'' by [[Lafcadio Hearn]] also consists of original retellings. Yanagita published a collection '{{nihongo
column5: Tohno Monogatari}}' (1910) which featured a number of fanatastical ''[[yōkai]]'' creatures such as [[Zashiki-warashi]] and [[kappa (folklore)

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: ''namidabanashi'', sad stories; ''obakebanashi'', ghost stories; ''ongaeshibanashi'', stories of repaying kindness; ''tonchibanashi'', witty stories; ''waraibanashi'', funny stories; and ''yokubaribanashi'', stories of greed. (These are not standard or commonplace terms or classifications, except perhaps warai banashi. Tonchi banashi is a term but perhaps not a category.)
In the middle years of the 20th century storytellers would often travel from town to town telling these stories with special paper illustrations called [[kamishibai]].
Below is a list of well-known Japanese folktales:

date=November 2016}}: the superhuman Golden Boy, based on folk hero Sakata no Kintoki
[[File:The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter - Discovery of Princess Kaguya.jpg
about a mysterious girl called Kaguya-hime who is said to be from the capital of the moon
the story of a teakettle which is actually a shape-changing tanuki
the story of the old man that made the flowers bloom
a [[Jizō]] statue given a straw hat and is grateful
the story of an old man who drops rice into a mouse hole
the story of the tongue-cut sparrow
who rescued a turtle and visited the bottom of the sea
a man with a large wen (tumor, kobu) on his cheek, and how he loses it
[[File:Rabbit's Triumph - climax of the Kachi-kachi Yama.markings of Ogata Gekko.detail - image for k-k y article.version 1.wittig collection - painting 22.png

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Tongue-cut sparrow''': A washer woman cut off the tongue of a sparrow that was pecking at her rice starch. The sparrow had been fed regularly by the washer woman's neighbors, so when the sparrow didn't come, they went in the woods to search for it. They found it, and after a feast and some dancing (which the sparrow prepared), the neighbors were given the choice between two boxes; one large and one small. The neighbors picked the small box, and it was filled with riches. The washer woman saw these riches and heard where they came from, so she went to the sparrow. She too was entertained and given the choice between two boxes. The washer woman picked the largest box and instead of gaining riches, she was devoured by devils.<ref name=piggott>Japanese Mythology: Library of the World's Myths and Legends, by Juliet Piggott</ref>

'''Mandarin Ducks''': A man kills a drake mandarin duck for food. That night he had a dream that a woman was accusing him of murdering her husband, and then told him to return to the lake. The man does this, and a female mandarin walks up to him and tears its chest open.<ref name=piggott/>

'''Tanuki and Rabbit''': A man catches a tanuki and tells his wife to cook it in a stew. The tanuki begs the wife not to cook him and promises to help with the cooking if he is spared. The wife agrees and unties him. The tanuki then transforms into her and kills her, then cooks her in a stew. Disguised as the man's wife, the tanuki feeds him his wife. Once he is done, the tanuki transforms back to his original form and teases the man for eating his wife. A rabbit that was friends with the family was furious, so he had the tanuki carry sticks and, while he wasn't looking, set these sticks on fire. Then the rabbit treated the burn with hot pepper paste. Finally, the rabbit convinced the tanuki to build a boat of clay, and the rabbit followed in a sturdy boat. The clay boat began to sink, so the tanuki tried to escape, but then the rabbit hit him in the head with an oar, knocking him out and making him drown.<ref name=piggott/>

'''Badger and Fox cub''': A badger, vixen, and the vixen's cub lived in a forest that was running out of food, so they came up with the plan of one of them pretending to be dead, the other disguising as a merchant, and the “merchant” selling the “dead” animal to a human. Then they would have money to buy food. The vixen pretended to be dead while the badger was the merchant. While the transaction was happening however, the badger told the human that the vixen wasn't actually dead, so the human killed her. This infuriated the cub, so he proposed a competition. They would both disguise as humans and go into the village at different times. Whoever guessed what “human” was the other first, wins. The cub walked towards the village first, but he hid behind a tree. The badger went into the village, and accused the governor of being the fox, so the bodyguards of the governor beheaded him.<ref name=piggott/>
The folklore of Japan has been influenced by foreign literature as well as the kind of [[spirit worship]] prevalent all throughout prehistoric Asia.
The monkey stories of Japanese folklore have been influenced both by the [[Sanskrit]] [[Indian epic poetry
column3: Chinese]] classic ''[[Journey to the West]]''.<ref>On the Road to Baghdad Or Traveling Biculturalism: Theorizing a Bicultural Approach to... By Gonul Pultar, ed., Gönül Pultar. Published 2005. New Academia Publishing, LLC. {{ISBN
column4: 0-9767042-1-8}}. Page 193</ref> The stories mentioned in the Buddhist [[Jataka]] tales appear in a modified form throughout the Japanese collection of popular stories.<ref>The Hindu World By Sushil Mittal. Published 2004. Routledge. {{ISBN
column5: 0-415-21527-7}}. pp93</ref><ref>Discovering the Arts of Japan: A Historical Overview By Tsuneko S. Sadao, Stephanie Wada. Published 2003. Kodansha International. {{ISBN

date=November 2016}}: ancient India]] were influential in shaping Japanese stories by providing them with materials. [[India]]n materials were greatly modified and adapted in such a way as would appeal to the sensibilities of common people of Japan in general, transmitted through China and Korea.<ref>Miraculous Stories from the Japanese Buddhist Tradition: The [[Nihon Ryōiki]] of the Monk Kyōkai By Kyōkai. Published 1997. Routledge. {{ISBN
column3: 0-7007-0449-3}}</ref><ref>The Sanskrit Epics By John L Brockington. Published 1998. Brill Academic Publishers. {{ISBN

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: **[[Banchō Sarayashiki]], the ghost story of Okiku and the Nine Plates.

**[[Tamamo-no-Mae]], a vixen-type [[yōkai]] monster, masquerading as a woman.
**[[Tokoyo]], a girl who reclaimed the honour of her samurai father.
**[[Ushiwakamaru]], about Yoshitsune's youth and training with the [[tengu]] of [[Mount Kurama

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: '''Burnie''' is a port city on the north-west coast of [[Tasmania]]. When founded in 1827, it was named Emu Bay, being renamed after William Burnie, a director of the [[Van Diemen's Land Company]], in the early 1840s. Burnie was proclaimed a city by [[Elizabeth II
At the 2016 Australian Census Burnie had an urban population of 19,385.<ref name=\"ABSUCL\"/>
Burnie is governed by the [[City of Burnie]] [[Local government in Australia
The key industries are heavy manufacturing, forestry and farming. The Burnie port along with the forestry industry provides the main source of revenue for the city.<ref>{{Citation
column3: title=Port of Burnie, Tasmania : port information
column13: df=dmy-all }}</ref> Burnie was the main port for the west coast mines after the opening of the [[Emu Bay Railway]] in 1897. Most industry in Burnie was based around the railway and the port that served it.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: After the hand over of the Surrey Hills and Hampshire Hills lots, the agriculture industry was largely replaced by forestry. The influence of forestry had a major role on Burnie's development in the 1900s with the founding of the pulp and paper mill by [[Associated Pulp and Paper Mills]] in 1938 <ref>{{cite news
column10: publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and the woodchip terminal in the later part of the century. The Burnie Paper Mill closed in 2010 after failing to secure a buyer.<ref>{{Citation

date=November 2016}}: 2016 census]] of Population, there were 19,385 people in Burnie - Somerset urban centre.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: * Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up  7.2% of the population.
* 85.4% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 2.5% and New Zealand 0.8%.
*  91.5% of people spoke only English at home.
* The most common responses for religion were No Religion 37.5%, Anglican 18.5% and Catholic 15.4%.<ref name=\"ABSUCL\"/>
As at June 2018 Burnie, together with nearby [[Wynyard, Tasmania
date=November 2016}}: Wynyard]] had an estimated urban population of 27,174,<ref name=ABSSUA>{{cite web
column3: title=3218.0 – Regional Population Growth, Australia, 2017-18: Population Estimates by Significant Urban Area, 2008 to 2018
column8: accessdate=25 October 2019}} Estimated resident population, 30 June 2018.</ref> having reduced slightly at an average annual rate of -0.27% year-on-year over the preceding five years.<ref name=ABSSUA/>

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Tasmania's third largest hospital, The North West Regional Hospital is on Brickport Road. It provides both in and outpatient services for general medicine, general surgery, orthopaedics, psychiatry, and paediatrics.
Burnie has a central business district with several national retailers. Just outside the CBD there are other major retailers including: Harvey Norman Superstore; Spotlight; Godfreys; SuperCheap Auto.

Other amenities include the multi-function \"Burnie Arts and Function Centre\" (formerly known as the Civic Centre), post office, police station, supreme court, public and private hospital, as well as numerous sporting and social organisations.
Burnie is also home to the Cradle Coast campus of the [[University of Tasmania]], and campuses of the [[Tasmania Tomorrow#The Tasmanian Polytechnic
date=November 2016}}: Tasmanian Polytechnic]] and the [[Tasmania Tomorrow#The Tasmanian Academy
column3: Tasmanian Academy]]. The University of Tasmania campus includes the Cuthbertson Research Laboratores run by the [[Tasmanian Institute of Agricultural Research]].

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: [[Burnie Airport]] is located in the adjacent town of [[Wynyard, Tasmania
date=November 2016}}: Wynyard]], a 20-minute drive from the City of Burnie.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Burnie Port is Tasmania's largest general cargo port<ref name=\"Tasports Statistics 2013-14\">{{cite web
column8: access-date=20 June 2015}}</ref> and was once Australia's fifth largest container port. It is the nearest Tasmanian port to Melbourne and the Australian mainland. As with other ports in Tasmania, it is operated by the government owned [[TasPorts]].<ref>{{cite news

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: The port currently operates as a container port with a separate terminal for the exportation of woodchips. The port was planned to be expanded in 2013 so that it could accommodate extra freight from the proposed north-west mines in the [[Tarkine]].<ref name=\"bpu\">{{Cite news
Burnie was the terminus of the former [[Emu Bay Railway]] company operations.  The railway line is now known as the [[Melba Line]].

date=November 2016}}: Devonport]] via the four lane [[Bass Highway (Tasmania)
column3: Bass Highway]] and a rail link which is used for freight purposes. Burnie is also connected to the [[West Coast, Tasmania
column4: west coast of Tasmania]] by the [[Murchison Highway]].

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Bus service [[Metro Tasmania]] provides transport around the city and its suburbs.,<ref>[http://www.metrotas.com.au/ Metro Tasmania website] {{webarchive
column3: date=2 January 2007 }}</ref> [[Redline Coaches]] provides daily coach services to several towns and to the city of Hobart.<ref>{{cite web

date=November 2016}}: City of Burnie}}The city of Burnie consists of a number of small suburbs including Parklands, Park Grove, Shorewell Park, Acton, Montello, Hillcrest, Upper Burnie, Romaine, Havenview, Emu Heights, South Burnie and Wivenhoe.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Burnie has an [[oceanic climate]] with mild summers and cool winters. The average temperature in summer ranges from 12 to 21 °C with drier days as warm as 30 °C, with around 16 hours of sunlight per day. In winter, temperature ranges from 6 to 13 °C, and only 8 hours of sunlight. Relative humidity averages over 60% for the year in the afternoon.

Burnie averages 994 mm of rainfall per year. Most of the rain is during the cooler months from May to October. The summer months bring constant daily sunshine and only occasional rainfall with temperatures up to 30 °C on the warmest and driest days. Nearly every day from January to March has a maximum temperature of 20–25 °C.

column3: title=Climate statistics for Round Hill, Burnie
column8: title=Climate statistics for Round Hill, Burnie

date=November 2016}}: source 2 = Bureau of Meteorology (1965–1993 sunshine hours)<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Climate statistics for Elliott Research Station

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: [[Australian rules football]] is popular in Burnie. The city's team is the [[Burnie Dockers Football Club]] in the [[Tasmanian Football League
date=November 2016}}: Tasmanian State League]]. Their ground is [[West Park Oval]].

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: [[Rugby union]] is also played in Burnie. The local club is the [[Burnie Rugby Union Club]]. They are the current [[Tasmanian Rugby Union]] Statewide Division Two Premiers and were promoted to the Statewide First Division for the 2008 season.

[[Soccer]] is also represented in Burnie, with [[Burnie United FC]] having four teams compete in the northern premier league; the women's team, under 18 team, reserve team and division one team. They also have youth sides in the under 14 and under 16 competitions. Their ground is located in [[Montello, Tasmania]].
Burnie hosts an ATP Challenger Tour tennis event, the [[Burnie International]], during the week following the Australian Open.
Athletics events include the annual [[Burnie Gift]] and [[Burnie Ten]].

date=November 2016}}: The Advocate]]'' newspaper was established in 1890 servicing the North West region. The mailroom is located in Burnie whilst the local press operations ceased in mid-2008 and were relocated to Launceston.{{Citation needed

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: Burnie has access to the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation
column5: Southern Cross]] television stations as well as all new free to air television stations.

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: There are two commercial radio stations, [[7BU]] at 100.9 MHz on the FM band and Sea FM on 101.7 on the FM band. Many Melbourne radio stations can be received in Burnie.{{Citation needed

column4: Burnie CBD and Port from Wilfred Campbell Memorial Reserve}}

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: * [[Cameron Baird]] – Australian soldier, posthumously awarded the VC for actions in Afghanistan
* [[Justin Heazlewood]] – Australian songwriter, author, actor and humourist also known as The Bedroom Philosopher
* [[Josh Earl]] – Comedian and former host of [[Spicks and Specks (2014 TV series)

date=November 2016}}: Eddie Jones]] – racist pigdog and Current head coach of the English rugby union football team

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: * [[Vicki O'Halloran]] – Administrator of the Northern Territory

date=November 2016}}: David Guest]] – Australian field hockey player. 2008 Olympic bronze medalist

,safe,Kevinerman91,"{{EngvarB: * [[Maverick Weller]]– AFL player-[[Gold Coast Suns]] and [[St Kilda Football Club]]
* [[Lachie Weller]] – AFL player-[[Fremantle Football Club]] and [[Gold Coast Suns]]
* [[Eli Templeton]] – AFL player-[[St Kilda Football Club]]

* [http://www.nfsa.gov.au/blog/2012/09/28/tasmanian-time-capsule/ Watch historical footage of Burnie, Hobart, Launceston and the rest of Tasmania] from the [[National Film and Sound Archive]] of Australia's collection.
